Intent-Based Networking - Concepts and Definitions Intent-Based Networking - Concepts and Definitions
draft-irtf-nmrg-ibn-concepts-definitions-03 draft-irtf-nmrg-ibn-concepts-definitions-03
Abstract Abstract
Intent and Intent-Based Networking (IBN) are taking the industry by Intent and Intent-Based Networking (IBN) are taking the industry by
storm. At the same time, those terms are used loosely and often storm. At the same time, those terms are used loosely and often
inconsistently, in many cases overlapping and confused with other inconsistently, in many cases overlapping and confused with other
concepts such as "Policy". This document clarifies the concept of concepts such as "Policy." This document clarifies the concept of
"Intent" and provides an overview of functionality that is associated "Intent" and provides an overview of the functionality that is
with it. The goal is to contribute towards a common and shared associated with it. The goal is to contribute towards a common and
understanding of terms, concepts, and functionality that can be used shared understanding of terms, concepts, and functionality that can
as foundation to guide further definition of associated research and be used as the foundation to guide further definition of associated
engineering problems and their solutions. research and engineering problems and their solutions.
This document is a product of the IRTF Network Management Research This document is a product of the IRTF Network Management Research
Group (NMRG). It reflects the consensus of the RG, receiving reviews Group (NMRG). It reflects the consensus of the RG, receiving reviews
from 8 members and explicit support from 14 (beyond the authors). It from 8 members and explicit support from 14 (beyond the authors). It
is published for informational purposes. is published for informational purposes.

4.1. Intent and Intent-Based Management 4.1. Intent and Intent-Based Management
The term "Intent" was first introduced in the context of Autonomic The term intent was first introduced in the context of Autonomic
Networks, where it is defined as "an abstract, high-level policy used Networks, where it is defined as "an abstract, high-level policy used
to operate a network" [RFC7575]. According to this definition, an to operate a network" [RFC7575]. According to this definition, an
Intent is a specific type of policy, provided by a user to provide intent is a specific type of policy provided by a user to provide
guidance to the Autonomic Network that would otherwise operate guidance to the Autonomic Network that would otherwise operate
without human intervention. However, to avoid using "Intent" simply without human intervention. However, to avoid using intent simply as
as a synonym for "Policy", a distinction needs to be introduced that a synonym for policy, a distinction that differentiates intent
differentiates Intent clearly from other types of policies. clearly from other types of policies needs to be introduced.
Intent-Based Management aims to lead towards networks that are Intent-Based Management aims to lead towards networks that are
dramatically simpler to manage and operate requiring only minimal fundamentally simpler to manage and operate, requiring only minimal
outside intervention. Networks, even when they are considered outside intervention. Networks, even when they are considered
"autonomic", are not clairvoyant and have no way of automatically autonomic, are not clairvoyant and have no way of automatically
knowing particular operational goals nor what instances of networking knowing particular operational goals nor what instances of networking
services to support. In other words, they do not know what the services to support. In other words, they do not know what the
"Intent" of the network provider is that gives the network the intent of the network provider is that gives the network the purpose
purpose of its being. This still needs to be communicated by what of its being. This still needs to be communicated by what informally
informally constitutes "Intent". That being said, the concept of constitutes intent. That being said, the concept of intent is not
"Intent" is not limited just to autonomic networks, such as networks limited just to autonomic networks, such as networks that feature an
that feature an Autonomic Control Plane Autonomic Control Plane [I-D.ietf-anima-autonomic-control-plane], but
[I-D.ietf-anima-autonomic-control-plane], but applies to any network. applies to any network.
More specifically, Intent is a declaration of operational goals that More specifically, intent is a declaration of operational goals that
a network should meet and outcomes that the network is supposed to a network should meet and outcomes that the network is supposed to
deliver, without specifying how to achieve them. Those goals and deliver, without specifying how to achieve them. Those goals and
outcomes are defined in a manner that is purely declarative - they outcomes are defined in a manner that is purely declarative - they
specify what to accomplish, not how to achieve it. "Intent" thus specify what to accomplish, not how to achieve it. Intent thus
applies several important concepts simultaneously: applies several important concepts simultaneously:
o It provides data abstraction: Users and operators do not need to o It provides data abstraction: users and operators do not need to
be concerned with low-level device configuration and nerd knobs. be concerned with low-level device configuration and nerd knobs.
o It provides functional abstraction from particular management and o It provides functional abstraction from particular management and
control logic: Users and operators do not need to be concerned control logic: users and operators do not need to be concerned
even with how to achieve a given Intent. What is specified is a even with how to achieve a given intent. What is specified is the
desired outcome, with the Intent-based system automatically desired outcome, with the IBS automatically figuring out a course
figuring out a course of action (for example, using an algorithm of action (e.g., using an algorithm or applying a set of rules
or applying a set of rules derived from the intent) for how to derived from the intent) for how to achieve the outcome.
achieve the outcome.
The following are some examples of intent, expressed in natural The following are some examples of intent, expressed in natural
language for sake of clarity (actual interfaces used to convey intent language for the sake of clarity (actual interfaces used to convey
may differ): intent may differ):
o "Steer networking traffic originating from endpoints in one o "Steer networking traffic originating from endpoints in one

particular vendor's equipment, even if this occurs at the expense particular vendor's equipment, even if this occurs at the expense
of reduced service levels." of reduced service levels."

o "VPN service must have path protection at all times for all o "VPN service must have path protection at all times for all

offline analysis whenever significant fluctuations in latency offline analysis whenever significant fluctuations in latency
across a path are observed." across a path are observed."

In an autonomic network, intent should be rendered by the network In an autonomic network, intent should be rendered by the network
itself, i.e., translated into device-specific rules and courses of itself, i.e., translated into device-specific rules and courses of
action. Ideally, it should not even be orchestrated or broken down action. Ideally, it should not even be orchestrated or broken down
by a higher-level, centralized system, but by the network devices by a higher-level, centralized system but by the network devices
themselves using a combination of distributed algorithms and local themselves using a combination of distributed algorithms and local
device abstraction. In this idealized vision, because intent holds device abstraction. In this idealized vision, because intent holds
for the network as a whole, intent should ideally be automatically for the network as a whole, intent should ideally be automatically
disseminated across all devices in the network, which can themselves disseminated across all devices in the network, which can themselves
decide whether they need to act on it. decide whether they need to act on it.
However, such decentralization will not be practical in all cases. However, such decentralization will not be practical in all cases.
Certain functions will need to be at least conceptually centralized. Certain functions will need to be at least conceptually centralized.
For example, users may require a single conceptual point of For example, users may require a single conceptual point of
interaction with the network. Likewise, the vast majority of network interaction with the network. Likewise, the vast majority of network
devices may be intent-agnostic and focus only (for example) on the devices may be intent-agnostic and focus only (for example) on the
actual forwarding of packets. This implies that certain intent actual forwarding of packets. This implies that certain intent
functionality needs to be provided by functions that are specialized functionality needs to be provided by functions that are specialized
for that purpose (which depending on scenario may be hosted on for that purpose (which, depending on the scenario, may be hosted on
dedicated systems, or cohosted with other networking functions). For dedicated systems or co-hosted with other networking functions). For
example, functionality to translate intent into courses of actions example, functionality to translate intent into courses of actions
and algorithms to achieve desired outcomes may need to be provided by and algorithms to achieve desired outcomes may need to be provided by
such specialized functions. Of course, to avoid single points of such specialized functions. Of course, to avoid single points of
failure, the implementation and hosting of those functions may still failure, the implementation and hosting of those functions may still
itself be distributed, even if conceptually centralized. be distributed, even if conceptually centralized.
Accordingly, an intent-based network is a network that can be managed Accordingly, an IBN is a network that can be managed using intent.
using intent. This means, it is able to recognize and ingest intent This means that it is able to recognize and ingest intent of an
of an operator, or user, and configure and adapt itself autonomously operator or user and configure and adapt itself autonomously
according to the user intent, achieving an intended outcome (i.e., a according to the user intent, achieving an intended outcome (i.e., a
desired state or behavior) without requiring the user to specify the desired state or behavior) without requiring the user to specify the
detailed technical steps for how to achieve the outcome. Instead, detailed technical steps for how to achieve the outcome. Instead,
the intent-based network will be able to figure out on its own how to the IBN will be able to figure out on its own how to achieve the
achieve the outcome. Similarly, an intent-based system is a system outcome. Similarly, an IBS is a system that allows users to manage a
that allows users to manage a network using intent. Such a system network using intent. Such a system will serve as a point of
will serve as a point of interaction with users and implement the interaction with users and implement the functionality that is
functionality that is necessary to achieve the intended outcomes, necessary to achieve the intended outcomes, interacting for that

to encompass also known or related concepts, resulting in "intent- to encompass also known or related concepts, resulting in "intent-
washing" that paints those concepts in a new light by simply applying washing" that paints those concepts in a new light by simply applying
new intent terminology to them. However, in some cases, this new intent terminology to them. However, in some cases, this
actually makes sense not just a marketing ploy but as a way to better actually makes sense not just as a marketing ploy but as a way to
relate previously existing and new concepts. better relate previously existing and new concepts.
In that sense and regards to intent, it make sense to distinguish In that sense and regards to intent, it make sense to distinguish
various subcategories of intent as follows: various subcategories of intent as follows:
o Operational Intent: defines intent related to operational goals of o Operational Intent: defines intent related to operational goals of
an operator; corresponds to the original "intent" term and the an operator; corresponds to the original "intent" term and the
concepts defined in this document. concepts defined in this document.
o Rule Intent: a synonym for policy rules regarding what to do when o Rule Intent: a synonym for policy rules regarding what to do when
certain events occur. certain events occur.
